title: Absence and presence
source_editors: Kate Fleet, Gudrun Krämer, Denis Matringe, John Nawas, and Devin J. Stewart
content: Absence and presence are Ṣūfī concepts for which the Arabic terms are, respectively, ghayba and ḥuḍūr (with some authors, ḥaḍra or shuhūd ). The duality of ghayba and ḥuḍūr is formulated as a pair of words of opposite or complementary meaning, as is often the case in Ṣūfism, for example, qabḍ (contraction)— basṭ (expansion), ṣaḥw (sobriety)— sukr (drunkenness), and fanāʾ (effacement)— baqāʾ (subsistence).

Ṣūfī authors have been unable to agree on terminology or on the usage and proper place of the terms ghayba and ḥuḍūr in their respective versions of Ṣūfī doctrine. Ghayba is commonly understood as the state of mental absence from the created world and openness to the presence (ḥuḍūr) of the divine (e.g., Sarrāj, 340). Ḥuḍūr may also be understood as the Ṣūfī's regaining of (self-)consciousness without at the same time distracting himself or herself from God. The two terms may also be used conversely, with ghayba for absence from things divine and ḥuḍūr for preoccupation with the created world.

Al-Hujwīrī (the famous author of a Ṣūfī handbook, from Ghazna, in present-day Afghanistan, d. shortly after 465/1072) discusses the relative merits of absence and presence, along with an analysis of the relative merits and disadvantages of sukr (drunkenness) and ṣaḥw (sobriety) (248f.). The place of absence and presence in the system of Ṣūfī states and stations has never been clearly defined. According to al-Qushayrī (Ṣūfī author, d. 465/1072) and Ibn al-Qayyim al-Jawziyya (well known Damascene Ḥanbalī, d. 751/1350), ghayba can be attained at any stage along the Ṣūfī path, the unveilings of divine secrets varying correspondingly: Ibn al-Qayyim typically warns against the temptations that might befall Ṣūfīs of various ranks while experiencing ghayba (al-Qushayrī, 38; Ibn al-Qayyim, 210ff.), but according to Kāshānī (a Persian Ṣūfī and translator of al-Suhrawardī; d. 735/1334–35; Dervish , 86) and ʿAmmār al-Bidlīsī (d. c. 600/1200; Zwei mystische Schriften , 85), for example, ghayba is never attained by those in the highest station but only by neophytes.

The duality of ghayba and ḥuḍūr has a certain affinity with the concepts of fanāʾ (effacement) and baqāʾ (subsistence). Unlike the latter, ghayba , as argued by al-Qushayrī, does not imply a substitution of the ṣifāt (attributes) of the deity for the mystic's personal ṣifāt but concerns only one's perception of reality. But according to al-Suhrawardī (an important Ṣūfī teacher, who spent most of his life in Baghdad, d. 632/1234), ghayba , understood as absence from created beings, is practically identical with fanāʾ (al-Suhrawardī, 478; trans. Gramlich, 453). While in al-Qushayrī's Risāla (“Treatise”) the Qurʾānic story of Zulaykha and her friends (Q 12:31) is given as an example of fanāʾ (37), Ibn al-Qayyim (3:210) and Kāshānī (87) believe that it exemplifies ghayba .

In Ṣūfī literature the concept of ghayba is thus projected back into the Qurʾān, but it appears that the term and the underlying concept did not gain wide circulation before the late third/ninth century. We do not find it in the earlier ṭabaqāt (“generations”) of the Ḥilyat al-awliyāʾ (“Adornment of the friends of God”), a biographical work on prominent Ṣūfīs attributed to Abū Nuʿaym al-Iṣfahānī (d. 430/1038). Nor does any personage whose opinions concerning the term are mentioned by al-Hujwīrī predate the third/ninth century. Al-Hujwīrī asserts that the doctrine of ghayba originated with Ibn Khafīf (a famous mystic of Shīrāz, d. 371/982), but because al-Hujwīrī mentions many authorities earlier than Ibn Khafīf, his statement should be taken with caution.

The concepts of absence and presence have retained the same range of meanings as in the early textbooks and have remained common in Ṣūfism up to the present (for later examples see al-Anqarāwī, d. 1041/1631–32, and Nurbakhsh, d. 2008, a master of the Niʿmatallāhī order).
